ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned formalisms and techniques of quantum mechanics relevant for quantum chemistry. For me, the first half of the course was a review of quantum mechanical systems that I had already seen (particle in a box, particle in a finite well, harmonic oscillator, rigid rotor), while the second half of the course went more deeply into advanced topics in quantum chemistry (hydrogen atom, variational theorem, perturbation theory, Hartree Fock, Configuration Interaction). This course is essential for my graduate studies and did a great job of introducing me to formalisms and theories that are directly relevant to my research. The course emphasizes concepts over technical math which feels like the appropriate way to introduce quantum chemistry to graduate students.
Feel more knowledgeable in the topic and comfortable reading material that requires understanding of the latter.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have liked the whole course to delve more deeply into the second half topics, but Sharon offers an informal seminar in the spring for this so I have the opportunity to do so.

I felt like the lecture content did not provide as much important content outside of the material provided by the book. Very undergraduate style instead of discussion based - which was the expectation since we can learn the material from the book. A reverse classroom setting would be much more useful. The topic is harder to apply in varied settings and that is the portion that is important to discuss and ask advice about how to solve and reason through.
honestly did not have any criticisms of the course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students intending to use computational chemistry in any capacity, this course is a must. For experimental chemists, this course still has value, but the second half of the course may be challenging without previous exposure to quantum mechanics.
Not really. I feel like the content is important but the class was not motivating and could have had a much greater positive outcome in terms of applicable knowledge than it did.
